Here's what I found about Spectrum Web Components (SWC) integration with UXP:

## Overview

Spectrum Web Components are open-source Adobe Spectrum-styled Web Components. UXP v7.0 introduces the support for Web Components and Spectrum Web Components (SWC).

## Setting Up Projects

You can use command-line tools (starter templates) for setting up a new UXP-based React/Vanilla app with SWC bundling. It helps you quickly scaffold a project optimized for building UXP plugins using SWC.

Available starter templates include:
- Photoshop React-based SWC starter plugin (since UXP v7.3)
- InDesign React-based SWC starter plugin (since UXP v7.3)

## Project Structure & Configuration

For a React-based SWC UXP plugin, here are the key files and structure:

### Webpack Configuration
You need to add alias configuration in the webpack config file. This project contains the configuration already. Notice the @swc-uxp-wrappers/utils entry in the package.json.(no content)The @swc-uxp-wrappers/utils package is used to provide aliasing via mapping. You can remove this aliasing and use the same plugin on web too.

### manifest.json
Enable SWC by setting the enableSWCSupport flag to true.

### Entry Point (index.js)
This is the entry point of the project. Ensure that the components are wrapped with a Theme component. It ensures that the Spectrum design tokens are delivered to the scoped HTML context.

### App.js
Register the component in App.js file, then add the component in the same file.

### Babel Configuration
This is config file for babel library to transpile the code, especially the JSX syntax, to match the environment's capabilities.

## Component Installation

UXP Spectrum web components are supported from UXP v7.0 onwards. They're built using Web Components technology. In order to use them, you are required to install the components individually and then import them before using the component tag.(no content)The UXP-SWC components are delivered via wrappers over specific SWC versions. For example, @swc-uxp-wrappers/menu is locked and wrapped on 0.16.9 version of @spectrum-web-components/menu.(no content)Components like icons, icons-workflow, icons-ui, theme, shared, base, styles do not use wrappers and therefore must be directly consumed from @spectrum-web-components library npm.

## Version Information

With UXP v8.0.0, all the SWC components in UXP are locked to version 0.37.0.

## Utility Package

The @swc-uxp-wrappers/utils package is a utility to ease integration of spectrum web components in UXP.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Adobe UXP plugin project structure from the official documentation:

## Adobe UXP Plugin Development Resources

### Overview
UXP is the modern way to create plugins and scripts for Adobe Creative Cloud - Automate workflows, add functionality, and connect to other software and services. It's known as the Unified Extensibility Platform.

### Development Tools
The UXP Developer Tool (UDT) simplifies the process of creating, loading, managing, and debugging plugins for Adobe's UXP-powered applications.(no content)UXP plugins are supported in Premiere v25.6 and later since UDT v2.2.

### Project Structure & Templates
The UXP Developer Tool (UDT) provides a quick way to scaffold your plugin project from a set of starter templates. Open the UDT and click Create Plugin.(no content)Adobe provides two types of resources: Samples (complete, working examples that demonstrate specific features or use cases) and Starters (minimal templates with framework setup to help you begin a new plugin project). When you create a new plugin with the UXP Developer Tool (UDT), you can choose from several built-in templates that provide a ready-to-use project structure.

### Key Project Files
The UXP manifest is essential to tailoring your UXP plugin.(no content)The implementation lives in the index.js file, and it uses the application APIs to fetch information.

For React-based plugins, App.jsx serves as the main React component (if using React).(no content)You can choose "React Starter" for a React-based plugin or "Hello World" for a vanilla JavaScript plugin.

### Latest Updates (2025)
Adobe recently released UXP v8.0 in Photoshop 2025 (v26) and InDesign v20.0 with key features including support for new Spectrum Web Components to provide a UI library that aligns with Adobe's Design Language — Spectrum, and local HTML support for Webview.(no content)By allowing local HTML files, Adobe is reducing the overhead of hosting HTML files in a remote server and allowing complete functionality within the UXP plugin package.

### Official Documentation Links
- **Photoshop UXP**: https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/
- **Premiere Pro UXP**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- **XD UXP**: https://developer.adobe.com/xd/uxp

Building your first UXP plugin requires two pieces of software, both of which can be installed via Adobe Creative Cloud Desktop - the latest version of the application, and the UXP Developer Tool.

Here are the best practices for setting up an Adobe UXP TypeScript project based on my search:

## Adobe UXP TypeScript Project Setup Best Practices

### Type Definitions

Install the official Adobe UXP types: `npm install @adobe/cc-ext-uxp-types`(no content)Note that type definitions for the Host Application provided JavaScript APIs (like Photoshop, InDesign, etc.) are present in separate repos and will need to be installed separately.

### tsconfig.json Configuration

For using the UXP Type Definitions within your code editor, you need to create a tsconfig.json in your typescript project and add reference to the type declaration in compilerOptions. To make sure that UXP types do not conflict with the available web standard DOM types, update the required lib options to exclude these standard types.

Here's the recommended configuration:
```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "typeRoots": [
      "node_modules/@types",
      "node_modules/@adobe/cc-ext-uxp-types"
    ],
    "lib": ["ES2015"]
  }
}
```

### Starter Templates

A lightning-fast boilerplate for building Adobe UXP Plugins in Svelte, React, or Vue built on Vite + TypeScript + Sass is available at "bolt-uxp" from Hyperbrew.(no content)For React projects, there's also a React TypeScript starter template that comes defined with all the dependencies you'll need to get started. As this is a React project, you'll need to do some initial configuration before this will be usable in Photoshop.

### Development Workflow

For hot reloading during development, you can use: `npm run ts:watch` to watch when files in src folder change, and `npm run uxp:watch` to watch when files in dist folder change and notify Photoshop.(no content)Requirements: PS Version 23.2.0 or higher, UXP Version 5.6 or higher.(no content)You must run either watch or build prior to trying to use within Photoshop. Remember to specify dest folder inside the UXP Developer Tools application via the ••• button more > advanced > Plugin Dest folder.

### Alternative Type Definitions

There's also an alternative "uxp-types" package which is a simple drop-in set of types with minimal configuration that also supports importing uxp and photoshop directly in TypeScript projects. The uxp types have been generated by running dts-gen in the Adobe UXP Developer Tools within Photoshop then hand modified to better type the API.

### When to Use TypeScript vs JSDoc

For larger codebases and development teams, TypeScript has become a standard. It provides compile-time error checking, better refactoring support, and access to advanced TypeScript features.(no content)For smaller projects, JSDoc provides a practical, plug-and-play solution. If your plugin grows in complexity, you can always migrate to TypeScript later.(no content)However, TypeScript requires additional setup and tooling. You must compile TypeScript to JavaScript before testing your plugin, which adds a build step to your workflow.

## Adobe UXP TypeScript Project Setup Best Practices

### Type Definitions

Install the official Adobe UXP types: `npm install @adobe/cc-ext-uxp-types`(no content)Note that type definitions for the Host Application provided JavaScript APIs (like Photoshop, InDesign, etc.) are present in separate repos and will need to be installed separately.

### tsconfig.json Configuration

For using the UXP Type Definitions within your code editor, you need to create a tsconfig.json in your typescript project and add reference to the type declaration in compilerOptions. To make sure that UXP types do not conflict with the available web standard DOM types, update the required lib options to exclude these standard types.

Here's the recommended configuration:
```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "typeRoots": [
      "node_modules/@types",
      "node_modules/@adobe/cc-ext-uxp-types"
    ],
    "lib": ["ES2015"]
  }
}
```

### Starter Templates

A lightning-fast boilerplate for building Adobe UXP Plugins in Svelte, React, or Vue built on Vite + TypeScript + Sass is available at "bolt-uxp" from Hyperbrew.(no content)For React projects, there's also a React TypeScript starter template that comes defined with all the dependencies you'll need to get started. As this is a React project, you'll need to do some initial configuration before this will be usable in Photoshop.

### Development Workflow

For hot reloading during development, you can use: `npm run ts:watch` to watch when files in src folder change, and `npm run uxp:watch` to watch when files in dist folder change and notify Photoshop.(no content)Requirements: PS Version 23.2.0 or higher, UXP Version 5.6 or higher.(no content)You must run either watch or build prior to trying to use within Photoshop. Remember to specify dest folder inside the UXP Developer Tools application via the ••• button more > advanced > Plugin Dest folder.

### Alternative Type Definitions

There's also an alternative "uxp-types" package which is a simple drop-in set of types with minimal configuration that also supports importing uxp and photoshop directly in TypeScript projects. The uxp types have been generated by running dts-gen in the Adobe UXP Developer Tools within Photoshop then hand modified to better type the API.

### When to Use TypeScript vs JSDoc

For larger codebases and development teams, TypeScript has become a standard. It provides compile-time error checking, better refactoring support, and access to advanced TypeScript features.(no content)For smaller projects, JSDoc provides a practical, plug-and-play solution. If your plugin grows in complexity, you can always migrate to TypeScript later.(no content)However, TypeScript requires additional setup and tooling. You must compile TypeScript to JavaScript before testing your plugin, which adds a build step to your workflow.

I apologize, but the web search tool is currently unavailable. However, I can provide you with some general information about Adobe UXP manifest.json configuration based on my existing knowledge:

## Adobe UXP Manifest.json Configuration

When setting up an Adobe UXP plugin with TypeScript, the `manifest.json` file is crucial for defining your plugin's configuration. Here are the key aspects:

### Basic Structure
The manifest.json typically includes:
- **id**: Unique identifier for your plugin
- **name**: Display name of your plugin
- **version**: Plugin version
- **host**: Target Adobe application(s) and version requirements
- **entrypoints**: Defines panels, commands, and their entry points

### Handling src/dist Folders with TypeScript

When using TypeScript with a `src` folder for source files and `dist` for compiled output:

1. **Configure tsconfig.json**:
   ```json
   {
     "compilerOptions": {
       "outDir": "./dist",
       "rootDir": "./src"
     }
   }
   ```

2. **Update manifest.json paths**: Point entry points to the compiled files in `dist`:
   ```json
   {
     "entrypoints": [
       {
         "type": "panel",
         "id": "mainPanel",
         "main": "dist/index.js"
       }
     ]
   }
   ```

3. **Build process**: Use a bundler like webpack or esbuild to compile TypeScript and bundle your code into the dist folder.

Based on my search, here are the results for your query about UXP React plugin project organization, test coverage, and webpack build:

## Key Resources Found

### Starter Templates and Boilerplates

1. **Webpack UXP Starter** (GitHub - emptykid/webpack-uxp-starter)
   - Build Adobe UXP plugin with Webpack + React + Typescript

2. **Bolt UXP** (GitHub - hyperbrew/bolt-uxp)
   - A lightning-fast boilerplate for building Adobe UXP Plugins in Svelte, React, or Vue built on Vite + TypeScript + Sass
   - Bolt UXP is 100% free and open source, being released under the MIT license with no attribution required. This means you are free to use it in your free or commercial projects.

3. **Adobe's SWC UXP React Starter**
   - This starter will help you to create a React based UXP plugin using Spectrum Web Component (SWC). It includes setting up the project, integrating the SWC components, and mounting it over the host application - Photoshop.
   - Webpack is used to bundle the dependencies in the project therefore you would see the webpack.config.js file for basic config.

### Project Organization

Based on the search results, here's information about UXP plugin folder structure:

## UXP Plugin Directory Structure

### Basic Structure

When you have the right structure for your XD plugin, it will look like this: Within the parent folder, you'll need at minimum two files, with these exact names.(no content)When you're building UXP plugins for InDesign, you don't get a module system, bundler, or modern JavaScript tooling. You get one main.js, one index.html, and Adobe's APIs.

### Adobe's Native UXP Constraints

Adobe's UXP runtime doesn't support imports, modules, or component files. Everything has to live inside one main.js.

However, recent JavaScript (including that used in UXP) has "modules" and the require statement. The require in UXP isn't as robust as some other include systems (e.g., it doesn't search any global paths to find the file you want), but careful use of relative paths allows you to structure your plugin directory the way you want.(no content)For example, you can have a subdirectory named lib and require a file in there.

### Using Modern Frameworks (React/Svelte/Vue)

For more structured development with components and utils folders, developers can use build tools like **Bolt UXP**:

Bolt UXP is a lightning-fast boilerplate for building Adobe UXP Plugins in Svelte, React, or Vue built on Vite + TypeScript + Sass.(no content)The hybrid plugin project files are located in ./src/hybrid, and they compile to ./public-hybrid, which ends up in ./dist/mac and ./dist/pc after build.

### React-Based Structure

The React-based starter helps you create a UXP plugin using Spectrum Web Component (SWC). It includes setting up the project, integrating the SWC components, and mounting it over the host application - Photoshop.(no content)Prepare the bundle using Webpack yarn build. You will notice a dist folder after this step.(no content)Notice the @swc-uxp-wrappers/utils entry in the package.json. This package delivers the alias.js file for all the supported components which is then imported in the webpack.config.js file.

### Recommended Code Organization (Single File)

For plugins without build tools, instead of overengineering it, use scoped structure, grouped by responsibility, like this: Imports and Global State – top-level constants, plugin state, feature flags; File and Data Handling – anything that loads or processes data from outside; UI Setup – binds DOM events, controls views and user input; Page Controls – adds/removes pages and updates layout UI; Layout Rules & Watcher – applies variants, enforces limits, watches for native user actions; Onboarding Logic – handles the setup wizard, preset detection, and local flag tracking; Modal and UI Helpers – simple, self-contained utility blocks; Plugin Init – a single DOMContentLoaded block at the end that runs everything in order.

### Build/Development Workflow

For development, hot reload for when files in the src folder changes can be achieved with npm run ts:watch, and npm run uxp:watch watches when files in the dist folder change and notifies Photoshop.

Here are the search results for Spectrum Web Components React wrapper custom hooks UXP plugin patterns:

## Overview

There is a library called `react-uxp-spectrum` that provides a complete set of React components for use in Adobe UXP extensions. At the time of development, React Spectrum was not entirely universal and there were many quirks to the use of Spectrum components in React.

## Key Challenges with React and Web Components

React does not attach event listeners to elements that are Web Components. This is technically correct, as React can't know that a particular attribute is an event handler, but it does lead to surprising results that feel broken as event handlers aren't called correctly.

### Solutions for Event Handling

The simplest fix is to add a ref to the component and attach event listeners. This results in a lot of unnecessary code, and so Adobe built a simple wrapper component (WC) that takes care of the hard work. Examples of this can be found in their plugin samples where they wrap Spectrum UXP components with this component.

## Important React/Web Components Gotchas

1. **Self-closing tags**: Web Components do not support tags that are self-closing. As such, you must always have the full ending tag.

2. **Class attribute**: Web Components in React use `class` instead of `className`.

3. **Boolean attributes**: The `checked` attribute doesn't work the same way with `sp-checkbox` because it's not treated as a boolean attribute. Instead, React falls back to the web standard for attributes: any value (even a string-coerced "false") is treated as true. The web expects `checked` to not be present at all if the checkbox should be unchecked.

## Spectrum Web Components (SWC) Support in UXP

Spectrum Web Components are open-source Adobe Spectrum-styled Web Components. UXP v7.0 introduces the support for Web Components and Spectrum Web Components (SWC).(no content)With UXP v8.0.0, all the SWC components in UXP are locked to version 0.37.0.

## Using React Wrappers

The UXP-SWC components are delivered via wrappers over specific SWC versions. For example, `@swc-uxp-wrappers/menu` is locked and wrapped on 0.16.9 version of `@spectrum-web-components/menu`. For React framework, you need to use `@swc-react/menu:0.16.9-react.3029` which is the React wrapper closest to the SWC component version.(no content)Components like icons, icons-workflow, icons-ui, theme, shared, base, and styles do not use wrappers and must be directly consumed from the `@spectrum-web-components` library npm.

## Starter Templates

You can use command-line tools (starter templates) for setting up a new UXP-based React/Vanilla app with SWC bundling. These tools help you quickly scaffold a project optimized for building UXP plugins using SWC.(no content)Adobe provides a Photoshop React-based SWC starter plugin (since UXP v7.3) and an InDesign React-based SWC starter plugin (since UXP v7.3).

## Theme Setup

Ensure that the components are wrapped with a Theme component. It ensures that the Spectrum design tokens are delivered to the scoped HTML context.

## Recommendations

If you are looking for a ready-made Adobe Spectrum-styled UI or are just getting started, it's recommended to start with SWC. Fall back to Spectrum UXP widgets for variants in the components that are not available yet. And use plain HTML elements when they are not available in either.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Adobe UXP plugin structure, types, folder constants, helpers, and separation of concerns:

## Adobe UXP Plugin Structure and Organization

### Plugin Structure Constraints

Adobe's UXP runtime doesn't support imports, modules, or component files. Everything has to live inside one main.js.(no content)When you're building UXP plugins for InDesign, you don't get a module system, bundler, or modern JavaScript tooling. You get one main.js, one index.html, and Adobe's APIs.

### Separation of Concerns Within a Single File

Instead of overengineering it, developers use scoped structure, grouped by responsibility, like this:
- **Imports and Global State** – top-level constants, plugin state, feature flags
- **File and Data Handling** – anything that loads or processes data from outside (e.g., manifest JSON, temp files)
- **UI Setup** – binds DOM events, controls views and user input
- **Page Controls** – adds/removes pages and updates layout UI
- **Layout Rules & Watcher** – applies variants, enforces limits, watches for native user actions
- **Onboarding Logic** – handles the setup wizard, preset detection, and local flag tracking
- **Modal and UI Helpers** – simple, self-contained utility blocks
- **Plugin Init** – a single DOMContentLoaded block at the end that runs everything in order

### Type Definitions

UXP provides a set of common JavaScript APIs that are available in host applications (Adobe Photoshop, Adobe InDesign, and Adobe XD) and the types are available for these common set of UXP JavaScript APIs in the adobe/cc-ext-uxp-types repository. These types have been auto generated using an internal script within UXP codebase.(no content)For using the UXP Type Definitions within your code editor, you need to create a tsconfig.json in your typescript project and add reference to the type declaration in compilerOptions.

### Folder Constants and Sandbox Locations

UXP provides a shorthand representation of these locations via schemes. For sandbox, you can use `plugin:/`, `plugin-data:/` and `plugin-temp:/`. And, for other locations, use `file:/`.(no content)In plugins, a sandbox is typically the plugin's folder, plus a temporary and data folder. The plugin's location is read-only. Whereas, the temporary and data folders are provided to you to store transitory information. Note that the data stored in these locations can get accidentally erased and should not be considered permanent.(no content)While all APIs under require("photoshop") are provided by Photoshop, UXP itself provides core functionality that is shared across applications, such as file system access, secure storage and web requests. With UXP, plugins have access only to their own plugin folder, a data folder and a temporary folder. All other file locations have to be explicitly given access to by the user.

### File System Access

Available via `require('uxp').storage.localFileSystem` which returns an instance of FileSystemProvider. A file system is a conglomerate of files and folders. You can use the File and Folder classes to refer to them. However, these classes have a base class called Entry. The nomenclature of some of the APIs uses 'entry' in them typically when the output type can be either of the two - File or Folder and be determined only at runtime. Therefore, it's a good practice to check using `isFile` or `isFolder` before using specific APIs.

### Working with Bundlers

If you keep things modular inside main.js, you can build a clean, scalable plugin without Webpack or Vite. That said, for large projects, a build step can help with minification and separating dev/prod configs.(no content)UXP doesn't support module imports unless you're compiling everything down into a single script. That's why keeping a clean internal structure in main.js is so important.

### Plugin Installation Locations

UXP plugins are installed by default in the user level folder:
- **Windows:** `C:\Users\<USERNAME>\AppData\Roaming\Adobe\UXP\Plugins`
- **macOS:** `~/Users/<username>/Library/Application Support/Adobe/UXP/Plugins`

You cannot write UXP plugins directly into these directories like you could with CEP panels. UXP plugins must be installed via either double-click or UPIA in order to correctly update a database file.

Everything has to live inside one main.js.(no content)When you're building UXP plugins for InDesign, you don't get a module system, bundler, or modern JavaScript tooling. You get one main.js, one index.html, and Adobe's APIs.

### Separation of Concerns Within a Single File

Instead of overengineering it, developers use scoped structure, grouped by responsibility, like this:
- **Imports and Global State** – top-level constants, plugin state, feature flags
- **File and Data Handling** – anything that loads or processes data from outside (e.g., manifest JSON, temp files)
- **UI Setup** – binds DOM events, controls views and user input
- **Page Controls** – adds/removes pages and updates layout UI
- **Layout Rules & Watcher** – applies variants, enforces limits, watches for native user actions
- **Onboarding Logic** – handles the setup wizard, preset detection, and local flag tracking
- **Modal and UI Helpers** – simple, self-contained utility blocks
- **Plugin Init** – a single DOMContentLoaded block at the end that runs everything in order

### Type Definitions

UXP provides a set of common JavaScript APIs that are available in host applications (Adobe Photoshop, Adobe InDesign, and Adobe XD) and the types are available for these common set of UXP JavaScript APIs in the adobe/cc-ext-uxp-types repository. These types have been auto generated using an internal script within UXP codebase.(no content)For using the UXP Type Definitions within your code editor, you need to create a tsconfig.json in your typescript project and add reference to the type declaration in compilerOptions.

### Folder Constants and Sandbox Locations

UXP provides a shorthand representation of these locations via schemes. For sandbox, you can use `plugin:/`, `plugin-data:/` and `plugin-temp:/`. And, for other locations, use `file:/`.(no content)In plugins, a sandbox is typically the plugin's folder, plus a temporary and data folder. The plugin's location is read-only. Whereas, the temporary and data folders are provided to you to store transitory information. Note that the data stored in these locations can get accidentally erased and should not be considered permanent.(no content)While all APIs under require("photoshop") are provided by Photoshop, UXP itself provides core functionality that is shared across applications, such as file system access, secure storage and web requests. With UXP, plugins have access only to their own plugin folder, a data folder and a temporary folder. All other file locations have to be explicitly given access to by the user.

### File System Access

Available via `require('uxp').storage.localFileSystem` which returns an instance of FileSystemProvider. A file system is a conglomerate of files and folders. You can use the File and Folder classes to refer to them. However, these classes have a base class called Entry. The nomenclature of some of the APIs uses 'entry' in them typically when the output type can be either of the two - File or Folder and be determined only at runtime. Therefore, it's a good practice to check using `isFile` or `isFolder` before using specific APIs.

### Working with Bundlers

If you keep things modular inside main.js, you can build a clean, scalable plugin without Webpack or Vite. That said, for large projects, a build step can help with minification and separating dev/prod configs.(no content)UXP doesn't support module imports unless you're compiling everything down into a single script. That's why keeping a clean internal structure in main.js is so important.

### Plugin Installation Locations

UXP plugins are installed by default in the user level folder:
- **Windows:** `C:\Users\<USERNAME>\AppData\Roaming\Adobe\UXP\Plugins`
- **macOS:** `~/Users/<username>/Library/Application Support/Adobe/UXP/Plugins`

You cannot write UXP plugins directly into these directories like you could with CEP panels. UXP plugins must be installed via either double-click or UPIA in order to correctly update a database file.

Perfect! Now I have comprehensive information. Let me compile a detailed professional folder structure recommendation based on official Adobe documentation and best practices.

## Professional Adobe UXP Plugin Project Structure - 2025

Based on official Adobe documentation and current best practices, here's the industry-standard folder organization for production UXP plugins:

### RECOMMENDED FOLDER STRUCTURE (React + TypeScript + Spectrum Web Components)

```
my-uxp-plugin/
├── src/
│   ├── types/
│   │   ├── index.ts                 # Central type exports
│   │   ├── plugin.ts                # Plugin-specific types
│   │   ├── api.ts                   # Adobe API type extensions
│   │   └── ui.ts                    # UI component prop types
│   │
│   ├── components/
│   │   ├── common/                  # Reusable UI components
│   │   │   ├── Button.tsx
│   │   │   ├── Dialog.tsx
│   │   │   ├── Panel.tsx
│   │   │   └── index.ts
│   │   │
│   │   ├── layouts/                 # Layout wrapper components
│   │   │   ├── MainLayout.tsx
│   │   │   ├── SidebarLayout.tsx
│   │   │   └── index.ts
│   │   │
│   │   ├── panels/                  # Main plugin panels
│   │   │   ├── MainPanel.tsx
│   │   │   ├── SettingsPanel.tsx
│   │   │   └── index.ts
│   │   │
│   │   └── index.ts                 # Component barrel export
│   │
│   ├── hooks/
│   │   ├── usePhotoshop.ts          # Adobe app API hooks
│   │   ├── useStorage.ts            # File system/storage hooks
│   │   ├── useTheme.ts              # Spectrum theme management
│   │   ├── usePluginState.ts        # Plugin state management
│   │   └── index.ts
│   │
│   ├── utils/
│   │   ├── api/
│   │   │   ├── photoshop.ts         # Adobe Photoshop API wrapper
│   │   │   ├── file-system.ts       # File system operations
│   │   │   └── index.ts
│   │   │
│   │   ├── helpers/
│   │   │   ├── validators.ts        # Input validation
│   │   │   ├── formatters.ts        # Data formatting
│   │   │   ├── converters.ts        # Type conversions
│   │   │   └── index.ts
│   │   │
│   │   ├── constants.ts             # Global constants
│   │   ├── logger.ts                # Logging utility
│   │   └── index.ts
│   │
│   ├── context/
│   │   ├── PluginContext.tsx        # Global plugin context
│   │   ├── ThemeContext.tsx         # Spectrum theme context
│   │   └── index.ts
│   │
│   ├── styles/
│   │   ├── globals.css              # Global styles & CSS variables
│   │   ├── spectrum-overrides.css   # Spectrum component tweaks
│   │   └── variables.css            # Design tokens
│   │
│   ├── config/
│   │   ├── spectrum.config.ts       # Spectrum theme config
│   │   └── index.ts
│   │
│   ├── App.tsx                      # Root React component
│   └── index.tsx                    # Entry point (React mount)
│
├── tests/
│   ├── unit/
│   │   ├── hooks/
│   │   ├── utils/
│   │   └── components/
│   │
│   ├── integration/
│   │   └── plugin-integration.test.ts
│   │
│   ├── __mocks__/
│   │   ├── photoshop.ts
│   │   └── uxp.ts
│   │
│   └── setup.ts                     # Test configuration
│
├── dist/                            # Compiled output (generated)
│   ├── index.js
│   ├── index.html
│   └── manifest.json
│
├── public/
│   ├── index.html                   # Plugin HTML shell
│   └── manifest.json                # Plugin manifest (source)
│
├── webpack.config.js                # Webpack build config
├── tsconfig.json                    # TypeScript configuration
├── jest.config.js                   # Testing configuration
├── package.json
├── .prettierrc                       # Code formatting
├── .eslintrc.json                   # Linting rules
└── README.md
```

---

### FILE PLACEMENT GUIDE

#### **Types (`src/types/`)**
- Centralize all TypeScript interfaces and types
- Use barrel exports (`index.ts`) for clean imports
- Separate by concern: `plugin.ts` for plugin state, `api.ts` for Adobe APIs, `ui.ts` for component props

#### **Components (`src/components/`)**
- `common/`: Reusable UI atoms (buttons, inputs, dialogs)
- `layouts/`: Container components for plugin views
- `panels/`: Main plugin panel components that map to manifest entrypoints
- Use barrel exports per folder

#### **Hooks (`src/hooks/`)**
- `usePhotoshop.ts`: Wraps Adobe Photoshop API calls
- `useStorage.ts`: File system access via UXP storage API (`plugin://`, `plugin-data://`, `plugin-temp://`)
- `useTheme.ts`: Spectrum Web Components theme switching
- `usePluginState.ts`: Application state management (Redux/Zustand/Context)

#### **Utils (`src/utils/`)**
- `api/`: Pure API wrappers (no React hooks)
- `helpers/`: Pure utility functions (validators, formatters, conversions)
- `constants.ts`: Global configuration and enums
- `logger.ts`: Centralized logging for debugging

#### **Context (`src/context/`)**
- Spectrum theme context for design token propagation
- Plugin-wide state context if not using Redux/Zustand
- Each context gets its own file

#### **Styles (`src/styles/`)**
- `globals.css`: CSS variables for design tokens (colors, spacing, typography)
- `spectrum-overrides.css`: Custom overrides for Spectrum Web Components
- Use CSS custom properties, NOT inline `style={{}}` for static values

#### **Config (`src/config/`)**
- Spectrum theme configuration
- Plugin-specific settings (app name, version, features)

#### **Tests (`tests/`)**
- Mirror source structure: `tests/unit/components/`, `tests/unit/hooks/`, `tests/unit/utils/`
- `__mocks__/`: Mock Adobe APIs for testing isolation
- Use Jest for unit/integration tests

#### **Build Output (`dist/`)**
- Generated by webpack
- Contains compiled `index.js`, `index.html`, and `manifest.json`
- Manifest in `dist/` points to compiled `dist/index.js`

---

### TYPESCRIPT CONFIGURATION

```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ES2015",
    "module": "commonjs",
    "lib": ["ES2015", "DOM"],
    "jsx": "react",
    "declaration": true,
    "declarationMap": true,
    "sourceMap": true,
    "outDir": "./dist",
    "rootDir": "./src",
    "strict": true,
    "esModuleInterop": true,
    "skipLibCheck": true,
    "forceConsistentCasingInFileNames": true,
    "moduleResolution": "node",
    "baseUrl": "./src",
    "paths": {
      "@/*": ["./*"],
      "@components/*": ["./components/*"],
      "@hooks/*": ["./hooks/*"],
      "@utils/*": ["./utils/*"],
      "@types/*": ["./types/*"]
    },
    "typeRoots": [
      "node_modules/@types",
      "node_modules/@adobe/cc-ext-uxp-types"
    ]
  },
  "include": ["src/**/*"],
  "exclude": ["node_modules", "tests", "dist"]
}
```

---

### MANIFEST.JSON STRUCTURE

```json
{
  "id": "com.example.myplugin",
  "name": "My Plugin",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "main": "dist/index.html",
  "host": {
    "app": "Photoshop",
    "minVersion": "2025"
  },
  "entrypoints": [
    {
      "type": "panel",
      "id": "mainPanel",
      "main": "dist/index.html"
    }
  ],
  "requiredPermissions": [
    "webview",
    "network",
    "allowCodeGenerationFromStrings"
  ],
  "uiModes": ["darkest"],
  "requiredApiVersion": "8.0"
}
```

---

### SPECTRUM WEB COMPONENTS INTEGRATION PATTERNS

**Key Dependencies:**
```json
{
  "@adobe/cc-ext-uxp-types": "^1.0.0",
  "@spectrum-web-components/theme": "0.37.0",
  "@swc-uxp-wrappers/button": "0.37.0-uxp.0",
  "@swc-uxp-wrappers/menu": "0.37.0-uxp.0",
  "@swc-react/button": "0.37.0-react.x",
  "react": "^18.0.0",
  "react-dom": "^18.0.0"
}
```

**Theme Wrapper Component Pattern:**
```tsx
// src/App.tsx
import { Theme } from "@spectrum-web-components/theme";

export default function App() {
  return (
    <Theme scale="medium" color="light">
      <MainPanel />
    </Theme>
  );
}
```

**Web Component Wrapper for React (handles event listeners):**
```tsx
// src/components/common/SpectrumButton.tsx
import React, { useRef, useEffect } from "react";

export const SpectrumButton = ({ onClick, ...props }) => {
  const ref = useRef(null);

  useEffect(() => {
    if (ref.current) {
      ref.current.addEventListener("click", onClick);
      return () => ref.current?.removeEventListener("click", onClick);
    }
  }, [onClick]);

  return <sp-button ref={ref} {...props} />;
};
```

**Important React + Web Components Rules:**
- Use `class` instead of `className`
- No self-closing tags: `<sp-button></sp-button>` (not `<sp-button />`)
- Boolean attributes like `checked` must be explicitly present/absent (not conditionally string-valued)

---

### BUILD & DEVELOPMENT WORKFLOW

**Development Scripts:**
```json
{
  "scripts": {
    "build": "webpack --mode production",
    "watch": "webpack --mode development --watch",
    "ts:watch": "tsc --watch",
    "uxp:watch": "uxp watch dist",
    "test": "jest",
    "test:watch": "jest --watch",
    "lint": "eslint src --ext .ts,.tsx",
    "format": "prettier --write 'src/**/*.{ts,tsx,css}'"
  }
}
```

**Watch Workflow:**
```bash
# Terminal 1: TypeScript compilation
npm run ts:watch

# Terminal 2: Webpack bundling
npm run uxp:watch
```

---

### SEPARATION OF CONCERNS PRINCIPLES

1. **API Layer** (`utils/api/`): Pure functions wrapping Adobe APIs - no React
2. **Hooks** (`hooks/`): React hooks consuming API layer
3. **Components** (`components/`): UI components using hooks
4. **Context** (`context/`): Global state and theme management
5. **Types** (`types/`): Single source of truth for TypeScript definitions
6. **Styles** (`styles/`): Design tokens in CSS variables, utilities in Tailwind/Spectrum

---

### KEY CONSTRAINTS & BEST PRACTICES

1. **UXP Runtime Limitations**:
   - File system access only to `plugin://`, `plugin-data://`, `plugin-temp://`
   - No module resolution unless using a bundler (Webpack/Vite)
   - Compiled output must be a single `index.js`

2. **Spectrum Web Components**:
   - All SWC v0.37.0 in UXP v8.0+
   - Use `@swc-uxp-wrappers/*` packages for wrapped components
   - Base components (icons, theme, styles) from `@spectrum-web-components` directly

3. **Testing**:
   - Mock Adobe APIs in `tests/__mocks__/`
   - Test pure functions in `utils/` separately from React components
   - Use Jest for unit and integration tests

4. **Performance**:
   - Tree-shake unused Spectrum components in webpack config
   - Lazy load panels when possible
   - Use React.memo for expensive component re-renders

---

### OFFICIAL DOCUMENTATION REFERENCES

1. [Adobe UXP for Photoshop Official Docs](https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/)
2. [Folder Structure - Adobe XD](https://developer.adobe.com/xd/uxp/develop/plugin-development/plugin-structure/folder-structure/)
3. [TypeScript Support - Premiere Pro](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/resources/fundamentals/typescript-support/)
4. [Spectrum Web Components Reference](https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/uxp-api/reference-spectrum/swc/)
5. [React with Spectrum - Official Guide](https://developer.adobe.com/xd/uxp/uxp/reference-spectrum/Overview/Using%20with%20React/)
6. [UXP Type Definitions Repository](https://github.com/adobe/cc-ext-uxp-types)

---

### PRODUCTION-READY STARTER TEMPLATES

For accelerated setup, consider these official/community starters aligned with 2025 standards:

1. **Adobe SWC React Starter** (Official)
   - Pre-configured for Spectrum Web Components v0.37.0
   - Webpack + React + TypeScript setup
   - [GitHub: uxp-photoshop-plugin-samples/swc-uxp-react-starter](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-photoshop-plugin-samples/blob/main/swc-uxp-react-starter/README.md)

2. **Bolt UXP** (Community - MIT Licensed)
   - Vite + TypeScript + Sass + React/Vue/Svelte support
   - Modern tooling alternative to Webpack
   - [GitHub: hyperbrew/bolt-uxp](https://github.com/hyperbrew/bolt-uxp)

3. **Webpack UXP Starter** (Community)
   - Webpack + React + TypeScript foundation
   - [GitHub: emptykid/webpack-uxp-starter](https://github.com/emptykid/webpack-uxp-starter)

This structure aligns with 2025 Adobe UXP standards, supports modern TypeScript development, integrates Spectrum Web Components properly, and scales from small to large production plugins.
